title: Replicator Dual: extruder fix based on Makerbot Rep2 fix

description.text: This variant uses the hardware available from the Makerbot store - just tweaks the hinge point to ensure it fits and works under the Replicator dual top mount.

The source files are there if you want to tweak things further for any reason. The original suggestion of setting the wall thickness to 3 and fill to 10% works well.  
UPDATE: There is an additional STL which has been exported from Rhino3D with some different settings which should make it easier to print with the latest version of Makerware. (The previous version works fine with Skeinforge/ReplicatOrg)

comments.text: what size spring do you use for this?
comments.author: skuhnheim

comments.text: Ok, I've printed this out several times and I've got a set on my Replicator 1 Dual working nicely. Things I found out.
comments.author: ChuckMcM

comments.text: This mesh is non manifold. Makerbots latest slicer creates extra plastic. What did you use to export this ?
comments.author: clubclay

comments.text: Interesting. I have reloaded the above STL file in Rhino and it shows no non-manifold edges. Netfabb also shows that the STL has no problems. So I am not sure why you think it non-manifold... In any case  as noted in the instructions, the source files are available in Rhino (3DM) and STEP formats. Let me know what software is showing this STL as non-manifold... I am curious.  I print using ReplicatOrg generally because of its greated control so would not pick up a makerware problem. cheers R
comments.author: clubclay

comments.text: Thanks Rod. I use blender for mesh checking, it has a 'select non manifold' option in point and edge edit modes. In your .stl, every time there was a transition from high to medium res subdivisions, there was no stitching geometry to marry up the transition, it was just lots of points left in mid air - spatially on another edge - but not actually joined / welded. The latest MakerWare slicer started to add weird diagonals when it printed, it obviously looked okay when rendered, but that doesn't mean its manifold / watertight.
comments.author: RodLaird

comments.text: I went back into Netfabb and found that indeed it showed some holes (which it can of course repair.).
comments.author: clubclay

comments.text: Cool. Give Blender a whirl for validation, it's free, but a little hard to use. That may seem like an understatement when you first load it up :) It still won't detect crossed quads and the like, just failings in basic topology (i.e. open edges)
comments.author: RodLaird

comments.text: I tweaked the Rhino3D STL export settings and have put up a clean version of the STL here too...
comments.author: clubclay

comments.text: Great job Rod, Blender gives the new file (NO_ERRORS) the all clear, looks like a good clean export - what were the changes you made, should I ever decide to use Rhino ? I won't print the new file (my printer is fixed now - yay!) but, for your information, I was using MakerWare 2.2.0.49. Thanks again for the Replicator (1) Dual mod that uses the purchasable hardware kit - this was convenient for me.
comments.author: RodLaird

comments.text: There is an optional export flag for STLs that allows for "Jagged seams". Your comment on the resolution transition problem clued me that this may be the issue. Disabling this option cleaned the STL...
comments.author: clubclay

comments.text: Is that 'Jagged Seams' flag on by default ?
comments.author: RodLaird

comments.text: Is that 'Jagged seams' flag on by default ? If so, that's dumb....

author: RodLaird

description.text:
I determined that using all four of the magnetic mounts on my Creator Bod 3D printer was causing the magnets to pull the plate into a slight warp making it impossible to level the bed. By using the front Two L-shaped brackets with the metal tabs removed from the front of the plate, the warp is now gone. I've included all four, I only used the front two. Installation:
1 - Remove the two tabs fixed to the front of the plate.
2 - Replace the two stock brackets with the two you just printed. (You may want to put a thin coat of rubber cement on the bottom of the bracket to keep it from rotation when leveling the bed.) 3 - Get a piece of thin double sided 3M tape (not foam tap). you will want one side to stick to the bracket and work the side towards the glass so that it's just tacky and doesn't ad here to the glass plate. This will eliminate any shifting of the glass plate.
4 - Level the bed and have fun!

author: ICEPICKTONY

description.text:
I purchased several of the FRM01 timer relay modules and have found them very useful.  The problem is the manual was terrible.  I rewrote the manual for all to enjoy.  Hope I did not make too many mistakes.
V1.1 Change: A small change in the "Summary of Functions" table as per billredmann

comments.text: Hi Ward Elder, thank you so much for the great translation for the community. By high pulse on ch1 do you mean bridging the IN to DC+?
comments.author: edwardchew

comments.text: Thanks for creating this manual!  My head was spinning trying to understand which function to use and your manual simplified things greatly!  I noticed a couple things as I was specifically interested in the time ranges for my task.  I think for functions Functions 07, 08, 17 and 18 the time range is only 1-9999 sec and not the full 0.005 seconds to 270 hours since the time base can't change from 01 (pg 7-8), if it can change I would be interested to learn how.  Also I think the NX Functions for 01-06 and 11-16 also applies to function 10 as well (pg 12).  I could be mistaken though.
comments.author: granzow59

comments.text: I will have to check. I will see what I can figure out.
comments.author: granzow59

comments.text: Thanks awfully for the English language translation. I just bought a couple of FRM01's and I was getting a headache every time I tried to explore its capabilities on the workbench. I had just about completed designing and building a specialised sort of timer out of 4000 series CMOS logic chips. Forty year old technology! Then I stumbled upon this module which will do the same job and more in about one quarter of the space and at about one eighth of the cost. Still, it was a nice exercise and the effort of making the peripherals that attach to the timer was not wasted. Your manual will make sure that I'm using the FRM01 in the simplest possible way for the application.
comments.author: rover109

comments.text: Glad it helped.
comments.author: rover109

comments.text: Thanks so much for the Chinglish to English translation! Reading the original manual was giving me an headache. Must have taken a huge amount of time. The effort is very much appreciated!

(one typo:  in the table on page 5, The first two notes that say "Repeats when done" should be on modes 05 & 06 (not 04 & 05).  I spotted that because I'm using mode 06.  Thanks! (and I was able to find this on Google with no trouble).

comments.text: All fixed in V1.1 doc.  Thanks for the catching that error.

description.text: Checkerboard and checkers Set

This thing is a refinement of my prior WallyWorld Moose Mug. After re-watching the youtube clip a couple of times, I decided to made the following changes: nose (longer & more tapered), nostrils (on the side of the nose), antlers (more realistic, maybe?), and a rounder larger mug body shape. The dovetail attachment for the antlers is the same as the prior version, so you can select the antler version that you prefer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=fKncYRJQRC8#! I am not cooking or heating anything in this & do not intend to let any contents reside in it for very long. I intend to hand wash them after every use

Print the mug and two antlers (brown ABS if you have it or color it later). Clean up the tapered dovetail features until the antler tenon slips in & locks over the ridge at the bottom of the mug's mortise. Print at least two, one for you and an associate - or as many as you need.
Darken the eyes and nostrils with a colored pencil or by some other means, which will not be dissolved or wash off with a seal.
Seal for leaks with a wash of acetone and/or abs juice.
For storage between eggnog times: the antlers will slide off & fit inside.
CAPACITY: These holds about 200 ml (6.76 oz); filling it with 6 oz leaves a little brim room for walking about.

author: viktorh

description.text:
A  lock to suit Traditional Sliding Screen doors (5 parts).  
This lock is designed to suit a screen door 15.5mm thick.   
Unlike locks that I was able to find commercially this lock will allow you lock/unlock the door from both inside and out.

Print one each of the five parts. All parts can be printed without support you will just need to rotate/position them accordingly. Print Settings of current Test Lock: Layer Height:- 2.0
Infill:- 20% You will need to drill 3 holes through the door, 1 8mm centre hole for the shaft and two 6mm holes for the rods that connect the two handle parts. You may need to do a light sand to the square end of the shaft to fit into the lock part as it meant to be a snug fit. The shaft is slightly shorter then required so that you can tighten the lock up firm as the lock works on friction to work properly. I have uploaded the stl files but if requested I can upload the files in a different format, what ever Creo 2 permits. slidingdoorlock_combined.stl provided for viewing combined lock NOT FOR PRINTING

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

This spacer allows a smaller 1/5 scale servo to be used in place of the the designed for HS805BB servo. The servo pictured is a Blue Bird BMS-L530MG servo with dimensions of 29.6mm X 59.7mm which is shorter than the designed for motor size of 29.5mm X 65.6mm.

• Servo Spacer
    The Servo Spacer allows a Blue Bird BMS-L530MG or similarly sized servo to be used in place of the original designed for HITec HS805BB servo. Note: The BMS-L530MG servo is of similar specification for power/torque as the HS805BB servo. The BMS-L530MG servo size is 29.6mm X 59.7mm as compared to the HS805BB dimensions of 29.6mm X 65.6mm.
    • To use the Servo Spacer - Insert the shorter servo into the original holster. Be sure to orient the motor so that the output shaft spline will properly engage the gearing mechanism. Push the motor against one end of the holster then wedge the Servo Spacer into the resulting gap between the holster and the motor. There will not be a need to glue since the motor is fully wedged and is not commonly seeing any forces to push it out of the holster. Securely screw the supplied motor screws through the motor flange into the spacer.

title: Beer Grenade or Beer Fire extinguisher

description.text: Beer Grenade or Beer Fire extinguisher

Instructions:  
Print the 3 STL files – I used 15% infill for the prototype, but more infill would be better.  
I have also modified the Top part so the spring now works  
Parts you need:  
3D printer obviously for the 3 parts  
M3 bolt and nut (I used M3 x 10 and plain M3 nut) all I had at the time – if anything the bolt could be a good 3mm shorter, so get your junior hacksaw out.  
3.1 – 3.2mm drill bit just to clean out the holes – by hand you animals – not essential but would help (the model has 3.2mm printed holes)  
M3 split pin (if you don’t have them lying about in your workshop like I did; go to your local garage – they are used lots to keep castle nut on suspension parts of cars)  
Split ring or key ring – size not important but it must fit your split pin  
Full or empty beer can – I prefer empty – good excuse to drink the contents  
If you want the design to work – i.e. when you pull the pin the top / handle Knobs off – you will need a 3.5dia x 15mm spring – the one I used only just does the job so a higher spring rate would be better.  
The 4 holes at the bottom are just in case you want tap out to M3 for grub screws so it fixes to the can (I haven’t done this on the prototype) but should work.  
To the webmaster – sorry I have used photos of commercial products – I have no intention of promoting the products – but just let me know if you would like the logos photo shopped out and I will modify  
The prototype was printed on an i3  
If anyone wants the CAD files to make this much bettereeer just send me a message – I designed it in Inventor 2012 but I can convert to other formats if you want.  
ME!!

title: Longer than the ABP print
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Have you ever wanted to print a continuous object longer than 15cm with your stock Thing-O-Matic with ABP (Automated Build Platform)? Now you can! Well, sort of. This is concept is VERY early in development, but it works! This was an idea I while I was waiting for my Thing-O-Matic to come. A few days ago I started working one it and here it is. I am surprised that no one has tried this before. The closest case I found was thing 6607. ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6607 ) As it turns out, mrkim has already done something similar with thing 6552 using a 1X2 Reprap.( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6552 ) How does this work?
The printer prints part of the object and leaves an lip on one edge. Then moves the ABP's belt forward (4cm in this case) and prints another part of the object that has an overhang that fuses to the lip on the previous part. Future modification ideas:
  • Add a plate to prevent parts from drooping off the end of the ABP
  • Create a script that makes this style of printing a little more feasible
  • Build an encoder that tracks the distance that the ABP belt moved, thus improving the joining of the parts
    • Test History:
    0) Printed only the start piece. Forgot to remove the end.gcode stuff
    1) Printed a 7.4cm object with 2 segments on ABP belt @ 120C. Each segment at 4 cm long with a 5mm lip at each end.
    2) Printed a 11.2cm object with 3 segments on ABP belt @ 120C. Each segment at 4 cm long with a 5mm lip at each end.
    3) Printed a 14.7cm object with 4 segments on ABP belt @ 120C. Each segment at 4 cm long with a 5mm lip at each end.
    4) Printed a 26.5cm object with 7 segments on ABP belt @ 120C. Each segment at 4 cm long with a 5mm lip at each end.
    5) Move print position back to prevent part droop and printed a 28.5cm object with 7 segments on ABP belt @ 120C. Each segment at 4 cm long with a 10mm lip at each end.
    6) Printed a 24cm object with 7 segments on blue tape with no heat, thus eliminating any drooping. Each segment at 4 cm long with a 10mm lip at each end. Print Stats: (All stats are approximate)
    - Time: 15 min.
    - Plastic used: N/A
    - Cost (@ $0.024 USD per CC): N/A
    (Note: These values will change depending on your 3D printer and settings.) A video of test print 6 is available at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xZTXRhORQA0

Download "LongPrintActual v2 Download.gcode" and open in ReplicatorG
Search for "########" (Without the quotes) and replace with your Z Axis height.
Save the gcode file and print with your Thing-O-Matic. Note: This code has not tested this on any other Thing-O-Matic than my own. I am not responsible for any problems or damage that may occur when trying to print this object. Note 2: You may have to adjust the time that the ABP's belt moves in order to get the segments to link together correctly. The line to change looks like this:
G04 P2300 (wait t/1000 seconds)

description.text: This adaptor allows a standard sized servo to be used in place of the designed for large size servo in the InMoov robot Neck tilt mechanism.

• Neck Tilt-Motion Servo Adaptor
    The Tilt-Motion Servo Adaptor is to replace the designed for HS805BB servo motors of dimension - 29.6mm X 65.6mm with a Standard sized servo of dimensions - 20.1mm X 40mm. I used the TowerPro SG-5010 standard sized servo with 6Kg-cm to 11Kg-cm torque depending on where you read.
    • To use the Servo Adaptor - orient the adaptor so that the standard size servo output shaft spline will be properly located to attach to the Neck gear mehanism. I printed with ABS so I just pushed the Adaptor into place flush with the top of the designed holster and used a little acetone to glue the part into place. You then install your servo and screw into place. If you print with PLA or another plastic then use CA aka Super Glue, Epoxy, hot glue, etc.

author: bartwaw

description.text: These two parts - a 'Skull Rotation/Pan Servo Adaptor' and 'Neck Servo Horn Spacer' are to fit a standard sized servo in place of InMoov's original large size servo.

• Skull Rotation/Pan Servo Adaptor
    The Rotation/Pan Servo Adaptor has a bevel on the inside portion of one edge. This is so that you can install the Servo Horn Spacer onto the servo motor then insert the motor into the Adaptor.

    • To use the Rotation Adaptor, orient the bevel side down and towards the Neck gear. Now you are on your own for the order that you wish to install this. Note: Once the Adaptor is installed it will have captured the motor against the gear. You can now secure the adaptor with glue, screw or ??? Notice that you will NOT need to screw the output shaft to the servo horn or the spacer, or secure the motor onto the adaptor. The motor is subjected to twist/torque not up and down motions so once the adaptor has the motor captured between it and the gearing it will not come out.
  • Neck Servo Horn Spacer
    When using a Standard Sized Servo the output shaft will not reach to attach to the standard designed gearing. This Servo Spacer will bridge the gap between the smaller servo and the Neck gear.
    • This Servo Spacer is to be attached to the original gear via screw and or adhesive. I used both since it will be receiving constant back and forth rotation. Once the Spacer is attached to the gear - securely attach your servo horn to this spacer. Now, when you install the motor it will snug down into the servo horn not requiring to be screwed to it. If, you use and secure the above Servo Adaptor.

comments.text: If the motor is in good shape I have not noticed any noise other than common to servo motors. Is your buzz from loose wires or an interim position where the servo is trying to maintain the angle of rotation?
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: do you notice a buzzing sound using such small servos?

description.text:
Scaled down (scad files use actual sizes, I scaled it down in the assembly scad files) of a 5 feet by 3 feet dog by 3ish feet dog house. Uses mainly imperial units as the lumber (AFAIK) is in imperial units where I live (USA).   
Still a work in progress, designing it for my lovable pup! Hoping to add on a side panels, moulding, feeding area, strorage area, and porch attached to the front of the house.  
The scad files should contain the proper dimensions to build the actual full size dog house, although for the first like 70% of files I was converting all imperial units to mm, but by the end I just found it easier (for my when I start building) to use the imperial units and multiply it by the conversion factor (25.4) so in some files there will be mm and some will be imperial * 25.4.   
This is my first woodworking project as well, so hopefully things go well :) I guess it's possible to scale down the individual scad files, print them out, and glue it all together!

Universal Projector Leveller Do you have a problem with levelling your projector? Or maybe your projector doesn't have any levelling features?
Super easy tool for properly levelling your projector. I'm using it with upside down projector (cause of that my screen is lower than projector). Setup:
Print 4x part1 and 4x part2. STL files are for plywood 6mm tick, threaded rod 6mm and M6 nuts. (In the bottom of part2 you have to use nuts with rubber on the end. That will cure the unscrew effect while levelling.)
Plywood should be size of your projector. I cut threaded rod to 2x 10cm and 2x 20cm long parts. 3-4 pcs. M6 nuts for one corner Files:
Use "_remote" files in case of IR remote receiver in corner of projector.
You can also customise parts in SolidWorks by .SLDPRT files. Why?
Internal optics in lots of projectors are skewed up from horizontal position, in case of ordinary usage of the projector from table or ceiling. If projector is not on the table and is not screwed to the ceiling but little higher than projector screen, for best image you must lay it upside down on flat surface. In general, even with normal usage of projector someone may need this solution due to the lack of levelling feature in device.

description.text: I have a mini screen I use with my raspberry pi; see https://learn.adafruit.com/using-a-mini-pal-ntsc-display-with-a-raspberry-pi/overview. This is my first time creating a thing , and my first openSCAD experience. The first iteration did not print well at all, given that I had not yet learned that you can't print large spans of stuff with no support under it, but this one prints fine. It is a bit tricky to get the screen in, but as you see in the gallery, I managed to wrangle it in.

My wife asked that I come up with a solution. The problem was our dryer's door always came back to close while she was folding laundry.  Not life ending, but a nuisance anyway.  Here is my simple solution, and it worked first try.  The latch piece will need supports, unless like me, you don't care how it looks as long as it works.  I've included the 123D Design files so anyone can change it.
Replaces stock carriage slides. More fun than essential, but work well.

The bearings are 692ZZ 2x6x3 and fit opposite slides slightly off center so the whole carriage is supported along its length. I used a piece of filament for the axle that is heat seated on both sides. The plastic side may need some sanding to be flat and thin enough to properly fit under the carriage and a drop of oil now and again helps too.

comments.text: Yes... However, I think that that might not be a great idea because then the layers are along the direction of the clamp and it may be too weak.  I am a lot more trusting of the strength of printing it the way I have it.  If you try it out, let me know though!
comments.author: anewsome

comments.text:
Yes, I designed it this way to avoid delamination, I wanted a continuous movement around the holes :)
Your clamp should require only limited cleanup (to empty the 2 holes in the 3-tab head), but some slicers may "pollute" the clamp also. So you could print a non-rotated clamp and use a stock 2-to-3 tab rotated connector (or print one, where cleanup would then be very limited).
-cheers
comments.author: fehknt

comments.text: Yep, it really wasn't too bad, but certainly non-zero.  I ended up reaming out between the 'fingers' of the gopro side - it seemed to be a little too tight to fit as-is.  I'm not sure if that was due to the support or maybe just using .25mm layer height just wasn't good for the height differences needed and it made them too close.  30 seconds with a 3.5mm drill rubbed around in there did the trick. :)
comments.author: MoonCactus

comments.text: These are good ideas, but the gpro housing only has 2 fingers, so I think that the weak point would not get better even with 4 fingers on the other side... The housing plastic seems more robust than that of their ABS links but I would have better had 3 fingers on it than two.
comments.author: fehknt

comments.text: Ah, sorry I wasn't clear - I meant the 4 fingers could be used to build a replacement for the commercial 90 degree adapter.  So it would be 3 fingers (clamp) -> 4 fingers (90 degree) -> 3 fingers (other end of 90 degree) -> 2 fingers (gopro).  But this works arguably better overall.  FYI, I'm pretty sure their housing is polycarbonate.  I'd love to print in PC, but that'll require a serious hotend upgrade.  Also, it's a lot more expensive and absurdly hygroscopic...

description.text:
This is Facey.
A simple, geometric tabletop holder for your bills/papers! Just place it on a table and place folded bills and papers in the slots, instead of leaving them laying around and making a mess. The two holes are mostly there to make him look more like a.....face, but you can always keep a pen or pencil in there, for notes etc. This thing prints very well with no supports need.
I printed it at file size which is aprox. 58mm height and 115mm width, which I think it should be the minimum size to hold papers easily. Feel free to resize it as you see fit and please let me know if a bigger or smaller version worked for you.

This was printed with: Printer: Printrbot Simple Metal
Material: PLA/PHA
Filament: Colorfabb Intense Green
Temp: First Layer-200C / Rest-195C
Layer height: 0.2mm
Speed: Variable - around 55mm/sec
Shells: 3
Layers: Top/Bottom - 4
Infill: 20 (but you can always put some more in there for weight)
Supports: No
Time: aprox. 5 hours
Jigsaw Cookie Cutters

I printed one of the corner parts in PLA and it was a bit flexible and weak, but worked, so I printed again in ABS – stronger but still not sure – I might increase the wall thickness a bit. They are still prototype and a bit small (50x50 or 2”x2”) so I would recommend scaling them up a bit to your requirements. I planned to make them all interlockable but because cookie dough expands quite a lot during the cooking phase; this design will not work that way. The kids love them all the same So enjoy for now but please let me know what a good size should be (scale factor) and I will oblige and create a new version. ME!!
.
.
.
P.S.
You need to print all of the files once only; but if you want to create the square (that will NOT go together correctly due to expansion of dough or whatever you’re cooking) you need the following when creating your recipe: 4 x Top Right
1 x Mid Right
3 x Mid Bot
1 x Mid Not sure why I gave the files such stupid names but I did ---- Sorry about that ME - Again
.
.
.
.
Revision Notes - now added V02 of all files: V02 is reduced in height by 5mm (now 16mm) and scaled up to 150% (75mm Sq) and the wall is now 1.5mm thk so a good 3 passes. Have a play with both sizes - but don't mix them up Also make sure you print them with the flange on the bed (wrong way up) or as shown in the 3D image ME - Again again

description.text:
8mm Brackets – DIN and Umbilical cord  
2 brackets – designed for the Skeleton 3D Printer I made for my brothers printer, but will suit any 8mm shaft application similar  
I printed 8 of the DIN rail brackets – 4 to hold the 2 sets of DIN rail to the printer and 4 to replace the Arduino / RAMPs board mount with a sheet of Makrolon / Lexan  
And 1 of the Umbilical cord brackets to tie the main electrical cord back to the terminal rail  
These brackets are not just for a Skeleton 3D printer they are very handy for other printers with 8mm shafts.  
The DIN rail bracket uses an M3 screw and nut to clamp and an M5 screw to secure the DIN Rail or Mackrolon / Lexan plate – or whatever takes your fancy to mount the boards.  
The Umbilical cord bracket uses an M3 screw and nut to clamp and 2 x 2.5 X 100mm cable ties to secure the umbilical cord or whatever cable / device you need securing.  
I also screwed the Z axis voltage regulator to the umbilical cord bracket.  
Enjoy  
ME!!

An OpenSCAD module (STL also included) for a Canon EF-M lens mount (the lens side). My initial use for this was to make an adapter to connect my Canon EOS-M camera to a telescope. Hopefully this module is useful to others that want to make custom EF-M adapters. The design has a recess for the lock pin so it should bayonet and lock like a normal lens. The bayonet fins are tapered slightly for a better fit on the camera and should allow printing without any clean-up. There's also a channel for the electrical contacts so that the mount doesn't push them in too far - I had issues in earlier designs with a pin getting stuck in the pushed-in state. The camera-side of the mount includes a small alignment dot, but I would probably add a more visible dot to whatever is added to the mount. I was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10829, an EF lens mount, but did not directly use any of the design because EF-M is fairly different. The partial rotate extrude code from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34027 was extremely handy since it allowed me to easily make the more complex tapered bayonet fins.

title: Standoff for Power Distribution Board (45x45mm mounting hole distance | Ø3mm mounting holes)

description.text:
For boards with 45x45mm mounting hole distance, Ø3mm mounting holes. Standoff height: 6,5mm
Clearance between base and PDB: 5,5mm There are currently four versions for you to choose from: PDB 45x45_Ø2.5mm_M2.5:
Mounting pin Ø2,5mm on top, core hole for M2,5 on the bottom. PDB 45x45_Ø2.9mm_M2.5:
Mounting pin Ø2,9mm on top, core hole for M2,5 on the bottom. PDB 45x45_Ø2.5mm_M3:
Mounting pin Ø2,5mm on top, core hole for M3 on the bottom. PDB 45x45_Ø2.9mm_M3:
Mounting pin Ø2,9mm on top, core hole for M3 on the bottom. Choose between 2,5mm and 2,9mm pin depending on your printers accuracy. Core holes are designed 0,3mm larger to compensate shrinkage.
M2,5: Ø2.3mm
M3: Ø2,8mm

The Idea is that you mount the Board by melting down the top pins. Take a flat piece of metal (knife, spoon handle...) and heat it with a lighter. when heated up press it on the pin until it melts down.
Let it cool of for a few seconds and you can pull the piece of metal from the molten pin. (see last two pictures) After melting the pins, disassembly and reuse of the printed part is possible. Simply heat the molten pin for a very short time with a lighter and pull the board from the printed part.
Then it is ready for reuse.

description.text: Some tin cans do not have an indented lower lip to allow for easy stacking.  This becomes annoying in a crowded pantry.  The can stacking plate allows these problem cans to stack up to several levels.  I use my set every week when I unload the groceries.

Customizer asks for the diameter of the top of the can which you should measure.  It also asks for the height of the stacker. This needs to be 20mm for a can height of 110mm to grip the cans properly and stop them falling over.  
The stacker can be printed flat but you will definitely need support.  It has been designed to print vertically with the only overhang problem being at the very top.  Fortunately any drooping of filament tends to just grip the cans a little tighter - a useful benefit. A raft can help.  I find that it is best if the stacker has to be pressed to fit on a can.  This way the stacks can be pushed around at the back of the pantry without falling apart.  
My initial values are for Australian cans.  I am not sure of international variations.

title: Glass Bed Z-Axis Spacer for CTC & Flashforge Printers

description.text: This shim is designed to snugly clamp onto the board behind the z-axis and trigger the Z-axis 2.2mm earlier than normally would occur. This is to be used with the small 3/32" replacement glass pieces available at home depot. Simply cut the glass to size (6" by 9"), add the z-spacer, and clamp to your heated bed. Be sure to lower your print bed 5 or 6 turns to prevent the nozzle from crashing, and then level the surface again. While it is not borosilicate glass, the relatively slow heating process with relatively uniform heating should typically not cause the glass to crack. The flat surface of the glass should provide a much better uniformly flat surface than the stock print bed, many of which come slightly warped.

A mixed geometric/organic, angled pen holder inspired by honeycombs.
It gives a little bit of an angle to the pens and pencils it holds, making it easier to grab them when needed (I was always kind of annoyed that the pens I wanted to pick up from in front, where facing upwards!!!).
Also the perspective form of the sockets makes it easier to choose which pen you want to use. I have to note that damm301's Pen Holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73489/#instructions) , which is truly a great featured design, also gives an angle to the pens but in different way. This was not insired or derived by his pen holder (as I actually designed this before I ever so so it) but i have to acknowledge the slight similarity. I intend to upload a resized one in the near future...so you don't have to do it!
Also a split version is coming soon so that it can be printed in 2 colors (honeycomb slots - base)

This thing is a pretty big. It was designed to actually hold 2 pens in every honeycomb so if you print the file as it is you will get a pen holder with height: 16cm, width: 24cm and depth: 170cm that can hold up to 24 pens/pencils.
So unless anyone interested has a lot of pencils (and a lot of room on you desk) I would suggest you print this at about 65%-60% size, as i have done in the photos of the printed object. This will give you a more normal sized holder that can easily hold 12-15 pens/pencils. This was printed with: Printer: Printrbot Simple Metal
Material: PLA/PHA
Filament: Colorfabb Intense Green
Temp: First Layer-200C / Rest-195C
Layer height: 0.2mm
Speed: Variable - around 45-50mm/sec
Shells: 3
Layers: Top/Bottom - 3
Infill: 20 (but you can always put some more in there for weight)
Supports: No
Time: aprox. 11hours It might need a little bit of sanding for the tips at the top, if you want a better finished look.

title: Kuro's Compact Geared Bowden Pushfit Extruder

description.text: I modified Kuro's excellent MK7 based geared Bowden to use an M5 or M6 BSPT pushfit connector.  The hex nut retainer channel is gone, replaced with a bolstered hole for the pushfit.

BOM is the same as Kuro's, but replacing the 5/16" nut with the BSPT fitting. I've also added a couple of specialty things you might not have on hand:
  • 2 springs for idler tension
  • 3 625zz bearings
  • 1 MK7 drive gear
  • 1 M5x40mm hex headed bolt
  • 1 M5x30mm bolt
  • 2 M5 lock nuts (helps to avoid overtensioning the big gear axle)
  • 2 M3x35mm bolts
  • 1 M3x20mm bolt
  • 1 M3 x 6mm cup point grub screw
  • 2 M3x10mm bolt
  • 1 M5 or M6 BSPT pushfit for 4mm tubing
  • Assorted nuts and washers
    • Follow Kuro's instructions outside of the tube attachment. To mount the pushfit, use an appropriate wrench to slowly self-tap with the pushfit connector.

comments.text: This remix of Kuro's extruder is the best extruder I've ever made ( using stronger gears from another remix ). Now we are going to switch from MK7 gears to MK8 gears, and we still couldnt find any suitable extruder comparable to Kuro's. We came here to ask you to make another remix for MK8 gears :D

title: Wayfarer Modular Scifi Gaming Tiles: Core Set

description.text:
Finally, we here at IGG have a proper playground for our Pocket-Tactics models! I've been designing modular terrain tiles since I joined Thingiverse, but I hadn't quite found the right formula/scale until now. We magnetized ours using magnetic business cards cut and glued to the bottom and that worked amazingly well. Those and the magnetic whiteboard set us back $60 uh-merican, which wasn't too rough on the ol' Ill Gotten Games petty cash jar (which, I assure you, is rather petty). These are scaled for our Pocket-Tactics models (which is, maybe, 20mm scale?). If you want 28mm scale tiles, you might want to scale them up by 125% before printing. Oh, and all of these printed for us without supports. Enjoy! SHAMEFUL PLUG: - Oh, and if you're interested in the RPG we use these for, you can find Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder here in our Etsy store, in both PDF and book form: https://www.etsy.com/shop/IllGottenGames Also, these files are available for Tabletop Simulator, so check them out in the Steam Workshops if you own that game (and you should!)
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=402610623

title: Q450 Quadcopter Leg Landing Gear Extensions

description.text: This is a set of leg extensions for the Hobbyking Q450 quadcopter.  They will add 2 inches of ground clearance.  There are two options: Use a pair of leg extensions for each arm of the quadcopter.  They snap on and can be fastened into place with a single M3 x 12mm screw.  For those that want slightly less weight, you can use one leg extension in conjunction with a smaller retainer.  These options are shown in the photos.

First, print the "q450 legs sample" file.  This will print a pair of legs and a retainer.  From that, you can decide if this is going to work out for you, and if you want to go with the double leg option or the leg/retainer option.  Download the appropriate 3 pack to print the remaining parts for your quad all at once.

remixed_from.author: schlem
remixed_from.title: terraPin, a 120 Film Pinhole Photography System

description.text:
Add remote control to the terraPin camera's shutter! Make pinhole photos operating distant to the camera, or program an Arduino or similar for shutter control. These are alternative extensions for the terraPin 6X6 and 6X9 pinhole cameras
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:495230
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:577223
The only modifications are to the shutter blade and the body of the extension, which accommodates a small hobby servo to actuate the shutter blade via remote or automated control. I shot a few rolls out the back window of my Prius, controlling the Robo-Shutta from the driver's seat. Click the link for the Flickr Album. I have included a sketch for remote control with an Adafruit Trinket Arduino (semi-) compatible. The Trinket cannot output PWM, but a clever hack uses interrupts to simulate the necessary servo signal timing. Here's a video of a Trinket Arduino compatible microcontroller opening and closing a terraPin shutter

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

These are designed around the Common Sense RC-35 Ultra-Nano Servo. They're small, cheap and strong. The 6X9 Robo-Shutta uses small plates and 3mm bolts to clamp the servo in place. For best results, tap threads in the mounting holes. The 6X6 version is designed to mount with the tiny screws that come with the servo. You will need to drill mounting holes. You should be able to discern relative dimensions from the STL file viewer, but the 6X9 has more pieces. I used #12 piano wire to link the servo to the shutter blade. I used a heated tip of the #12 piano wire to quickly melt a hole in the shutter blade. It's a better method than 3Dprinting the tiny hole. Position the servo arm and the assembled shutter blade at their halfway points in their arcs of travel. Measure the distance between pushrod holes. Carefully shape your push rod from the #12 piano wire.

comments.text: The coding is actually pretty trivial. The inspiration for the robo-shutta was a remote control.  If you check out the Flickr album, you;ll see a few rolls I exposed while driving around taking pinhole photos of cars in traffic from the driver's seat (exciting in concept, boring in execution).  You totally could tie an Arduino into a calibrated light sensor and calculate the necessary exposure for the F/#, but I really enjoy that part of pinhole.  Again the code would be pretty easy.  What I would like to do is create a Bluetooth remote that would trigger the shutter from some distance, wirelessly.  For instance, I could make a pinhole photograph from a raised drawbridge and trigger it from the sidelines. Probably wouldn't make the NSA or FBI or other spooks super happy to be hanging a strange device from a bridge with magnets and controlling that something with a cellphone, but you get the idea of the potential for remote applications.

title: Fully Adjustable iPhone/ WebCam Mount for Flashforge/ Makerbot

description.text:
Updates:
The hook no longer needs supports
Units changed to inches so you don't have to convert
All-in-one file should now lay flat on bed
Thanks Hybrid_Potato for the feedback! I use an old iPhone as a webcam to monitor my prints. Since there's no good way to get a good angle, I made this little hook thing that lets you hang a phone or camera on a platform facing the printer bed. You can adjust it on all axes - adjust the height and depth, and slide it left and right to get a good angle.

I like printing multiple pieces at once. If that's your jam, too, use the STL with all 3 models. Otherwise, print the 3 pieces separately.  
The base has a hole for the arm to slide into, as does the hook. For the hook, I use supports (Simplify3D), so to get them out, I jab it with a screwdriver on each inner wall until it slides out.   
Assemble the model and hang it on the front of the printer. The front part of the hook is narrow enough to fit between the heat cover and the machine. If you're not sure what I'm talking about, check out the pictures!  
Note: The arm is a little longer and the bed a little wider than it indicated in the pictures. I made some adjustments to the STL files after that last photo set was taken.

title: Compound pulley and bearing plate for slowing a drill press

description.text:
I made these pulleys in an attempt to use a standard 12k/8k wood drill press for drilling stainless steel. I had previously been controlling the pressure by hand to partially stall the motor and slow it down to the requisite speed for drilling steel, but wore down a number of HSS-Co drill bits in the process. The original drill press had two compound pulleys:
  • driving pulley attached to the motor: 17mm and 22mm
  • output pulley attached to the drill head: 22mm and 33mm
    • This thing adds a bearing plate holding two standard 625 bearings (5x16x5) and compound pulleys that can be attached using M5 cap screws. Sources are here: https://github.com/hyperair/drill-press-pulleys

• Push the 625 bearings into the bearing plate.
  • Thread an M5 screw through each pulley and bearing, with an M5 washer in between.
  • Seal with an M5 nylock nut on the top.
  • Figure out how to route the belts correctly. Small to big, basically, going from the driving pulley to the output pulley. Don't assemble it in reverse unless you're sure the drill is going to be happy with it -- it totals up to about a 8x speed difference, so 12k RPM x 8 = 96k RPM. I'm not sure what will blow at that point.
  • Replace drill press safety cover before turning on in case the whole assembly explodes.

comments.text: I took the drill press on a test drive a couple of hours ago, and it successfully drilled a 2mm hole 30mm deep into a stainless steel screw. Looks like the pulleys do hold up to the torque of a drill press, even at 10% infill density. It does have 6x0.4mm perimeters though.

Hi n602, thanks for your great work. I have the "PiTFT Plus 480x320 3.5" TFT+Touchscreen for Raspberry Pi - Pi 2 and Model A+ / B+"
https://www.adafruit.com/product/2441. I printed the PiTFT_3p5inchLCD_base.stl, but the LCD 40pin female header hits the wall of the base. I then realised your LCD (2097) only had 26 pins so the base cut out would have fitted nicely. I'll try and modify your .123dx file. I'll post some pics of the 2441 and the case as it is now. Am I on the right track ? Thanks
comments.author: kelad

comments.text:
Thank you for your comment.
That's right, I am sure that you are on the right track.
.
When I designed this thing, PiTFT3.5" was the "product ID #2097" only in the line-up of adafruit.
New PiTFT3.5", "product ID #2441" was released after a while, and it had a 40 pin connector.
Although I thought that a part of "3p5inchLCD_base" might have to be cut off for newPiTFT3.5",
and cut a part of "3p5inchLCD_base" off for the trial and took photo for new PiTFT3.5"( I added a pic about this.),
I have not done it any more.
.
Please modify .123dx file and use for your project.
Good luck to you!
comments.author: kelad

comments.text: Having made it, some thoughts:  I can't get the ANKER Astro Mini 2nd Gen to power the Raspberry Pi 2.  Not sure if its just mine is defective or what, but curious which battery are you are using?  I also was unable to find the screws at any hardware store (you can online but I wanted to make sure they would fit before purchasing), so went with 4-40 X 1/2 nylon.  I used those with hexnuts and washers to attach the Raspberry Pi 2 to the bottom case.  It was problematic fitting the screws through the Adafruit 3.5 touchscreen (had to drill the holes out a bit).  The way the top printed, I just pushed them down (not really screwing them in).  I may add some super glue to them if it feels like its getting loose.  I also had issues getting any micro USB cord to plug into the Raspberry Pi because the 3D printed case got in the way.  Had to scrap the side a bit to allow the cord to fit properly.  I really loved the design and had a lot of fun putting it all together!

title: Connector Shield for powering two 3D printers

description.text:
I'm currently building a case that contains the PSUs and control boards and stuff to power up two 3D printers @24V. This is a shield/plate that is used to be mounted on the bottm/side of the box that leads every kind of connector that is needed for the printers to this single shield. Easy plugging and unplugging of the printers was the goal while designing this shield without scrabbling around inside the control box. It is designed to use the following types of connectors:
T-Connectors
Dupont Connectors
JST-XH Connectors Please take a look at the scetch I uploaded for clearance which connector is used for what.

As described in the sketch I used the following connectors for the shield: Nylon T-connectors (like this: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__30685__Nylon_T_Connectors_10_Pairs_20pc_US_Warehouse_.html)
for each of the DC Currents like Heatbed, Extruder Heater JST-XH 3S Connectors (like this: http://www.ebay.de/itm/Balancer-Verlangerung-fur-3S-11-1V-Lipo-JST-XH-20cm-Lipo-Kabel-Akku-/111610320792?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_77&hash=item19fc7e5798)
for connecting the stepper motors Dupont Connectos (3P, 2P) (like this: http://www.ebay.de/itm/100Stk-3P-Dupont-Jumper-Wire-Kabel-Stecker-Pin-Connector-2-54mm-Pitch-Weiblich-/181440433313?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_77&hash=item2a3eb14ca1)
to connect Termistors, LEDs, Fans and Endstops AC Plug (like this: http://www.ebay.de/itm/190942549649?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=490202350541)

author: Bash-T

title: Stack-able tin foil/plastic wrap/ cling wrap holder

description.text:
A stack-able holder for tin foil, plastic wrap, cling wrap, etc.. that comes in 12 inch tubes. Designed in small parts that should be glued together in order to work with smaller print beds.   
For stacking use the alternate bottom piece instead of the one for both top and bottom.   
If you're making the bottom piece/ only one dispenser use 4 of the top and bottom walls. If you're making one that will stack on top of a bottom one then use 2 of the top and bottom walls and 2 of the bottom walls.

author: Iniciativas3D

title: MK5-6 STEPSTRUDER NEMA 23 DIRECT DRIVE PIVOTING FILAMENT PUSHER

description.text:
This is a direct drive extruder mechanism that fits with the hotend and dinos of a MK5-6. I wanted to move to a stepper drive extruder but didn't want to wait three weeks for makerbot to ship their new beefy nema 17. I also had a lot of issues with the delrin plunger.
I liked the idea of a ball bearing to provide the pressure between the filament and the drive wheel as in a wade's but didn't like the 4 bolts to adjust to change filament.
My other design goals were to leave everything as accessible as possible and provide some mechanical advantage where it makes sense. The worm grove in the drive gear is made very close to the face of the motor while the motor shaft ball bearing rides at the end of the motor shaft while having the shaft pass completely through it.  I also increased the length of the teflon guide tube to come to right below the drive wheel.
The pivoting arm that applies pressure to the filament forcing it against the drive gear allows one screw and spring pair to take the job of four. It also means that the screw can be backed off completely and the arm rotated out of the way to provide access without having to be completely removed. The relative positions of the bearing and tensioning screw on the arm give something like a 2:1 advantage  of filament pinch strength vs spring force. 
I also included a hat that accepts a piece of sponge or similar to remove dust from the filament as it is being drawn into the extruder. The hat as well can pivot out of the way and has a sloping bottom to make it simpler to feed new filament through.
The sizing for everything is imperial in this case but I can make other versions is people have specific requests, I'll also include the source files.

The build process is fairly simple.
I used a nema 23 that is rated at about 144oz-in at 3amps because I had several lying around. In practice I have been running it at more like 2.5-2.75. The motor gets rather hot without any cooling but so far hasn't caused any problems. Most nema 23s I have found have four mounting holes at 0.205"(5.2mm) diameter. I tapped the aluminum face plate to 1/4-20 to simplify construction, it seems like an m6 tap would work as well. I taped over the holes to keep from getting swarf in the motor, its less likely to be a problem because its not magnetic but it still seems like a good idea. If you don't have taps  or don't want to permanently alter your stepper you could use nuts instead.
The tensioner arm is screwed together by two #6 x 1/2" sheet metal screw. The back half of the tensioner has a smaller holes for the sheet metal screws to dig into, the front holes should be a slip fit, I drilled them out to 1/8" before assembly. The back half is tapped for 1/4-20" ( or 6 or 8 mm ) for the bearing retainer screw. Both sides are put together and then the pivot hole was chased to 5/16". I have used both a 5/16" shoulder bolt with 1/4-20 threads and a 5/16" OD 1/4"ID sleeve bearing riding over a 1/4-20" bolt as a pivot. Both work fine. You could probably also get away with just using whatever bolt goes through the pivot corner riding on bare plastic. The shoulder bolt or bearing only cost around $1 so it made sense for me. 
The main body will likely need its holes chased depending on the size of your fasteners and the calibration of your printer. I drilled the stepper mounting holes to 1/4" along with the teflon tube support.
I chased both holes in the hat to 1/8"
If you have cut your MK5 teflon tubing to the length used in the original you may need to order more. In the states McMaster sells it for $2 a ft
8547K232 Tube Made Of Teflon(r) Ptfe, 1/4" Od X 1/8" Id, 1' Length
I've also bought 
8547K221 Tube Made Of Teflon(r) Ptfe, 1/4" Od X 1/16" Id, 1' Length
which looks like it should work with 1.75mm feedstock though I haven't tried it yet due to not having any 1.75mm plastic.

description.header: UPDATE I've tried the 1/4 X 1/16" teflon with makerbot 1.8mm abs with no luck, the much thicker wall of teflon makes it less able to stretch, I'll see if I can't find something else that fits
description.text:
To cut the right length I stuck the whole piece down the hotend and then slid the main body over it without the motor or the tensioner arm in place and then marked it and cut it off as close to the drive gear as I could get. The ball bearings I used were just ones I had lying around, 1/4" ID by 5/8" OD by 3/16" W
Others would work as long as they fit, the model could be changed or hacked on a bit after printing. My nema 23s have 1/4" shafts so I drilled the makerbot drive gear out on a lathe, that could probably be done with a drill press or hand drill because it is just expanding a hole slightly.

title: Power Supply stand for double HP DPS 600PB HP, PSU 24V

description.text:
I'm currently building a case that contains the PSUs and control boards and stuff to power up two 3D printers @24V. This is the stand to mount two 12V HP Power Supply units onto it so that we get a 24V 47A PSU. The stand is designed to meet the following conditions:
  • Sleek design
  • Standalone without any further mounting
  • Ability to mount the stand on a plate (to fix it inside my box in my case)
  • Allow enough air flow through the PSU's that will be sucked by the internal PSU fans.
  • Air flow from bottom to top
  • Holes for guiding the power and controller cables from the bottom of the PSU

The top and the base parts get screwed together with M5 threated rods that has to be cut to the correct length. The top plate has additional holes if you plan to secure the psu to the outside of an enclosing case (as I did). There is an excellent guide how to modify two of those 12V HP server PSU's to get 12 and 24V with 47Amps out of them. This should be enough to power several printers with heatbed :)
Each PSU costs only around 20bucks. Here is the guide:
http://www.ultimatercnetwork.com/forums/showthread.php?t=174225

The sugar bowl is nearly empty… too bad, no sugar in the house. So make a note to buy a kilo at the next shopping trip to the grocery.
This handy device holds a roll of paper. The type that is used in printing calculators and available in many book/office shops. This shopping list uses paper with a width of 45 mm and a roll diameter of 50mm. However, to adjust the unit to other dimensions, simply scale it in the slicer. Since a pen holder is part of it, it is easy to note the items you need to bring from the grocery shop next time. The pen or pencil rests on the lower support, so any size of pen or pencil fits in the holder.
Start writing at the bottom and fill the window upwards. When the window is filled up with shopping items, simply pull the paper down and continue making notes. At shopping time, pull the paper down until all the items are below the base plate and tear the paper off by pulling it. The bottom will act as a cutting blade, so you can take the list to the shop.
The unit is mounted to the wall with two screws. Place a spacer behind the unit around the screws. This insures enough clearance when the paper is pulled through. Do not overtighten the screws so the unit can be lifted off easily. Another option is dubble sided adhesive foam tape at the back, no drilling required. Alternatively, two 10mm neodymium magnets can be placed over the screw holes to make it fridge friendly (thanks for the tip Feiming). The paper slots are under an angle to facilitate paper transport. A simple decoration shows that the shopping list is for use in the kitchen. This version is for right handed persons. The pen holder is not in the way when writing.
To create one for left handed persons, simply change the indicated translate functions in the OpenSCAD file to move the pen holder to the right. This move is clearly commented in the SCAD file.
Make sure to hang it high enough. Otherwise the kids might grab it and use it as an endless drawing board or decorate the room with 20 meters of garlands.
This shopping list can be printed as one piece without support on any 3D printer, even on the small PrintrBot Simple.

This is a mount I designed and made for my Magellan Cylco 105 Speedo. I have two bikes so my Mountain bike got the Genuine mount and my old bike got the 3D printed version. I have included the Openscad source files so that you can make changes. See instructions.  
Inspiration from thing 96504 "Garmin Edge 510/810 Mount" by andiwu

The Openscad source file will allow you to change some parameters.
barDia: The diameter of the bar the speedo will mount on
barAngle: The angle between the mounting bar and the Speedo The bridge function is used so that you can print the top flange with minimal supports. Print with supports on and remove supports carefully. You will also need to remove the "bridge" carefully with a knife. I printed it in ABS as it is more flexible than PLA and easier to remove the support material. I used an old tube between the mount and the bar and then cable tie it in place. I have used this successfully for road riding and it seems quite sturdy. I wouldn't feel too comfortable with rough off road riding however

title: Fishing Line Pulley for my DIY Ultimaker

description.text:
2014-08-06: Uploaded a version for 6.35mm shaft as requested. 2013-10-18: Changed the files to two new designs in pretty high resolution. They are 20mm in diameter and 33mm high. It has 15 turns. When you use 2 turn for driving (as I do in my Rostock since a year) 13 turns for movement will remain.
20mm * 3.1415 = 62,8mm
62,8 * 13 = 816mm  --> This should be enough for your ultimaker.

Old Text:
I'm going to build my own derivate of an Ultimaker. I want to use the fishing line setup from my Rostock Delta Robot instead of a tooth belt. These are the two pulleys.
  • one with a 8mm hole for the axis' and
  • one with a 5mm hole for the stepper.

print the parts from ABS with a layer height of 0.175mm and you will get great results.

This is a Filament Spooler that I created for my Prusa I3. Living on the coast in a high humidity area, I decided to create a closed box Filament Spooler that I can put silaca crystals in to try and control moisture.  
It is designed to be placed inside a container and takes an 18mm dowel.  
You will need some M4 Nuts and Bolts in order to mount it in the container.  
Created in FreeCAD, included original source file.

The Inner mount is 10mm thick and is 40mm x 40mm in size.  
The outer mount is 5mm thick and is 40mm x 40mm in size.  
Print at normal scale. The samples shown are printed in Black ABS at 0.3mm layer thickness.  
Created in FreeCAD, included original source file.
Measures out portions for 1-4 servings
Made in SketchUp 2015 and printed with Wanhao Duplicator 4S with blue PLA.

title: Malyan M180 / Freesculpt EX2 - EZ-endStop optical trigger

description.text:
EZ-endStop optical trigger
Enhanced optical endstop trigger with offset of 1.00 / 2.00 / 3.00 / 3.50 mm.
The standard one is too thin, and sometimes with certain light conditions does some strange offset.
This one is more thicker, and gives 100% accuracy. /!\ PRINT IN BLACK /!\ or spray some black matte paint / schrinkable sleeve on it as i did.
Since optical endstop react to light change and not beam crossing, you need to print it in dark material, non reflective is a must. Like it and share your make !

comments.text: For those folks who keep saying "this isn't food safe," you have to remember that some materials -are- food safe, and other materials (like PLA) can be made from food-safe versions. comments.text: No, it's the design that's not food safe. All those tiny holes and cracks are breeding grounds for bacteria. It's impossible to get a proper clean down there. Look between the letters, around the P, inside the U. Areas like that are nearly impossible to clean properly. Water will pool there and bacteria will grow super fast.

Here are two wood carvings digitized with 123D-Catch.  The hammerhead shark is a souvenir of the Galapagos and the dolphin comes from Belize.  The shark is at 80% scale and the dolphin at 60% scale.

There are no flat surfaces on either carving.  A corner of each was cut off to make a flat surface for printing.  The small flat surfaces should be placed on the build platform and the carvings printed with support.

description.text: This sketch was the first design for our Foldie Qubic Meter 3D Printer

Designed in sketchup, this sketch was the first design for our Foldie Qubic Meter 3D Printer. We needed a bigger printer, so we built one out of Bosh-Rexroth profiles and 3D printed parts. It is currently been fitted with a triple Reprap based extruder. It can be folded, set upwards, and even has wheels on one side for transport.

comments.text: Do you have a 4 mm shaft for the dys motors??
comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: No, mine are 5mm
comments.author: tibuck

comments.text: i printed a few out and, either my prop shaft is indeed 5 mm( but they do say 4 mm)  or the fit is tight enough! because the fit nice and snug.  I printed  the test once out of pla,  and I found it prints nicely , so I will pull out the proto pasta carbine fiber pla to see if it takes some of the flex away. Let me know what your tried printing them with.
comments.author: Jamie96

comments.text: What is the pitch of the blades? Would it print & perform better if the base edge of the blades met the center?
comments.author: scratchymaster

comments.text: The blades have a 22 degree pitch, and I am curently trying out different designs with a wider edge to give more surface attached to the center, will let you know how well they turn out after some more testing.
comments.author: scratchymaster

comments.text: If my trig is correct, a 5045 prop has a 19deg blade angle. Do you notice your esc or motors running hotter?
comments.author: Jamie96

comments.text: Well my esc's ran quite hot anyway, so I can't really tell much difference. When I get a chance I will test them with some other props to see if there is much difference.
comments.author: scratchymaster

comments.text: Are they made to any naca foil series?
comments.author: anode505

comments.text: They don't actually have any airfoil profile (I'm not quite that good with 3d modeling) the blades are just flat, but so far they have proven to work alright.
comments.author: anode505

description.text:
This is a spacer for the lower spindle holder. It allows for an unmodified lower spindle holder to easily clamp the Dremel 100 Rotary Tool.  
I only needed two of the four spacers and the Dremel is solidly fixed in place.
